pageData.text: Blood groups are genetically determined, and not influenced by environmental factors. Blood typing is conducted to determine a person’s blood group. In this investigation, students are introduced to the ABO and Rh blood-typing systems, the process of <button class='glossary-text'>agglutination</button>, and the use of agglutination in the typing of human blood. Students carry out a blood-typing procedure using simulated (synthetic) blood and antisera.

text: Determine blood types using simulated blood and antisera.
Describe the factors determining ABO and Rh blood types and their inheritance.
Identify compatible blood types for transfusion.
Explain how parental blood type may affect the health of a fetus.

Predict <button class='glossary-text'>agglutination</button> reactions when incompatible whole blood encounters <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button> from blood <button class='glossary-text'>serum</button>.

pageData.text: Do you know your blood type? Maybe you have type A blood. You might even know whether you are positive or negative for Rh factor. It turns out that the ABO and Rh blood group systems are just two of many different systems used to categorize human blood. The International Society of Blood Transfusion (ISBT) maintains an official record of current blood group systems, of which there are 43. According to the ISBT, “the term ‘blood group’ usually refers to an individual’s combination of Red Blood Cell (RBC) surface <button class='glossary-text'>antigens</button>”<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. These antigens are part of RBC membrane proteins with a variety of functions, and it is these different proteins that distinguish each blood group. For example, the Duffy blood group system defines blood type by the presence of a certain receptor protein; the Gerbich blood group system focuses on certain structural components of the RBC cytoskeleton.

1ISBT. “Red Cell Immunogenetics and Blood Group Terminology: ISBT Working Party.” ISBT Working Party | The International Society of Blood Transfusion (ISBT),
https://www.isbtweb.org/isbt-working-parties/rcibgt.html.

pageData.desc: A cast-off blood stain pattern on light wall.
pageData.altText: A cast-off blood stain pattern on light wall.

pageData.text: When an individual must receive a blood transfusion, it is critically important to match his or her blood type to that of the appropriate donor. A mismatch could result in a serious and potentially fatal transfusion reaction. The reaction between mismatched blood types occurs because the recipient has <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button>, proteins generated by the immune system, in his or her blood <button class='glossary-text'>serum</button>, the liquid portion of the blood without clotting factors. These antibodies recognize and bind specifically to <button class='glossary-text'>antigens</button>, which are molecules on the surfaces of the donor’s red blood cells (RBCs). This causes clumping, or <button class='glossary-text'>agglutination</button>, of donor RBCs.

There are several different antigens on the surface of RBCs (Figure 1). The two most important types to consider for a blood transfusion are the <button class='glossary-text'>A</button> and/or <button class='glossary-text'>B antigens</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>Rh</button> (or <button class='glossary-text'>D</button>) <button class='glossary-text'>antigen</button>. The presence or absence of A and B antigens can be used to identify an individual’s blood type within the <button class='glossary-text'>ABO group system</button>. Someone with type A blood carries the A antigen on the surfaces of RBCs, and the immune system produces B antigen-specific antibodies. If he or she receives blood that was donated by someone with B or AB blood, the anti-B antibodies will bind to the B antigens and cause the RBCs to agglutinate. Likewise, a person with type B blood has the B antigen on the surfaces of RBCs and produces antibodies against the A antigen. Someone with type AB blood has both A and B antigens and does not produce antibodies against either antigen. An individual with type O blood does not have A or B antigens and generates antibodies against both A and B.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A table of the AB0 system of blood and the IgM antibodies present in the blood plasma

pageData.text: The Rh antigen belongs to the Rh blood group system, which was named for the rhesus monkeys in which it was first studied. An Rh-positive individual has the Rh antigen on the surfaces of RBCs and does not produce anti-Rh . An Rh-negative person lacks the Rh antigen and will produce anti-Rh antibodies. The Rh antigen is not only important for matching the transfusion to the recipient’s blood, but it is also a consideration during pregnancy and birth. is an often fatal condition that may occur when an Rh-negative woman carries an Rh-positive fetus. This situation can only arise if the father is Rh positive. If both parents are Rh negative, there is no risk of the fetus being Rh positive. However, if the fetus is Rh positive, the mother’s anti-Rh antibodies may cross the placenta, enter the bloodstream of the fetus, and attack the RBCs. HDN does not usually occur with the first Rh positive fetus, because the mother’s immune system is not exposed to the antigen until the time of birth. However, if the mother later becomes pregnant with another Rh-positive fetus, her immune system will produce anti-Rh antibodies. HDN once caused the deaths of many babies. However, an injection of anti-Rh antibodies during pregnancy can shield the antigen from the immune system, thus protecting the fetus.

pageData.question: The condition hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN) would likely occur in which of the following situations?

options.text: an Rh-negative woman carries an Rh-positive fetus
an individual with type A blood receives a donation of type O blood
an Rh-positive woman carries an Rh-positive fetus
an Rh-positive woman carries an Rh-negative fetus
an individual with type O blood receives a donation of type AB blood

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: HDN is an often-fatal condition that may occur when an Rh-negative woman carries an Rh-positive fetus.

pageData.question: What does it mean if an individual has type A blood?

options.text: They have A antigens on the surfaces of RBCs and produce anti-B antibodies.
They have B antigens on the surfaces of RBCs and produce anti-A antibodies.
They have A antigens on the surfaces of RBCs and produce anti-A antibodies.
They have Rh antigens on the surfaces of RBCs and produce anti-D antibodies.
They lack Rh antigens on the surfaces of RBCs and produce anti-B antibodies.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Someone with type A blood carries the A antigen on the surfaces of RBCs, and the immune system produces anti-B antibodies.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are several different antigens on the surface of RBCs. The two most important types to consider for a blood transfusion are the A and/or B antigens and the Rh (or D) antigen. The Rh antigen belongs to the Rh blood group system, which was named for the rhesus monkeys in which it was first studied. An Rh-positive individual has the Rh antigen on the surfaces of RBCs and does not produce anti-Rh antibodies. An Rh-negative person lacks the Rh antigen and will produce anti-Rh antibodies. The Rh antigen is not only important for matching the transfusion to the recipient’s blood, but it is also a consideration during pregnancy and birth.

The Rh antigen belongs to the Rh blood group system, which was named for the rhesus monkeys in which it was first studied. An Rh-positive individual has the Rh antigen on the surfaces of RBCs and does not produce anti-Rh antibodies. An Rh-negative person lacks the Rh antigen and will produce anti-Rh antibodies. The Rh antigen is not only important for matching the transfusion to the recipient’s blood, but it is also a consideration during pregnancy and birth.

pageData.text: When the ABO and Rh blood groups are combined, the basic information needed to start cross-matching blood donors and recipients is obtained. For example, someone with type A+ blood could safely receive blood from another individual with type A+ blood. In an emergency situation with no A+ donor blood available, he or she could receive blood from certain other blood types: A–, O+, or O–. Types B+, B–, AB+, and AB– could not be used, because the A+ recipient’s anti-B <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button> would cause the donated cells to agglutinate. It is important to remember that ABO and Rh are only two of several different groups of blood types, and there are some rare blood types besides these two commonly used systems.

The <button class='glossary-text'>antigens</button> and antibodies that are associated with each of the different ABO and Rh blood types are summarized in <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button> below.

The inheritance of blood types is well understood. The inheritance of ABO blood groups is of particular interest, because it provides an example of , which is a situation in which two different versions, or , of the same gene are both expressed. The I A or I B allele codes for enzymes that catalyze the binding of the A or , respectively, to the surface of RBCs. The i allele eliminates the ability to bind A or B antigens. Thus, an individual with the type A blood (observable trait) could have the (genetic makeup) I AI A or the genotype I Ai. Likewise, someone with type B blood could have genotypes I BI B or I Bi. Type AB blood requires the I AI B genotype, and type O blood requires the ii genotype.

People with type O blood were once thought to lack antigens on the surface of their RBCs, and those with type O– blood were referred to as “universal donors.” We now know that all ABO blood groups have a weak H antigen. The presence of the I A or I B allele actually codes for enzymes that catalyze the binding of the A or B antigen to the H antigen. The i allele eliminates the ability to bind the A or B antigen to the H antigen. Therefore, type O RBCs have more unbound H antigens.

The production of the H antigen is controlled by a gene locus with two <button class='glossary-text'>alleles</button> (H and h) on chromosome 19. These are independent of the ABO locus, which is on chromosome 9. Because the h allele is uncommon, the genotype hh is extremely rare. The hh individuals produce RBCs without the H antigen, and this is a condition called the <button class='glossary-text'>Bombay phenotype</button>, as it was first discovered in Bombay, India. In the absence of the H antigen, A and B <button class='glossary-text'>antigens</button> have nothing with which to bind. As a result, when individuals possessing the Bombay phenotype are tested with anti-A and anti-B <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button>, they appear to belong to group O. However, these individuals cannot receive blood from type O donors who have H antigens, because their hh RBCs are agglutinated by anti-H antibodies.

pageData.subTitle: Testing of Simulated Blood
pageData.text: The test procedures used in this investigation are the same as those used to test real blood. However, only simulated blood and antisera are included. This eliminates any risk that may be associated with the exposure to real blood or blood products. The materials in this kit may be discarded after use. There are no biological materials in the simulated blood or antisera that would cause health hazards when discarded.

pageData.question: In an emergency, someone with type A+ blood could receive which of the following types of blood?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Someone with type A+ blood could receive blood from certain other blood types: A–, O+, or O–. Other types could not be used because the A+ recipient’s anti-B antibodies would cause the donated cells to agglutinate.

pageData.question: In an emergency, someone with type O- blood could receive which of the following types of blood?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Someone with type O- blood could only receive more O- blood. This blood type contains antibodies against A, B, and D antigens, causing it to agglutinate any other blood types.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: When the ABO and Rh blood groups are combined, the basic information needed to start cross-matching blood donors and recipients is obtained. It is important to remember that ABO and Rh are only two of several different groups of blood types, and there are some rare blood types besides these two commonly used systems. People with type O blood were once thought to lack antigens on the surface of their RBCs, and those with type O– blood were referred to as “universal donors.” We now know that all ABO blood groups have a weak H antigen.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting, label the blood typing slide. In the activity, you will add a simulated blood sample to the slide wells, then add simulated antisera to their assigned wells. Next, stir the contents of each well and observe them for agglutination. Determine the blood type of the simulated blood sample, then rinse the blood typing slide. This process is repeated until 4 total simulated blood samples are tested.

This process is repeated until 4 total simulated blood samples are tested.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Important: Do not attempt to use real blood in this investigation. The simulated antisera will not work with real blood.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a safety hazard associated with this investigation?

options.text: There are no special safety concerns for this investigation.
The simulated antisera are toxic if inhaled.
The simulated blood samples are a corrosive material.
The blood typing slide is made of glass and could break.

assestmentData.question: Why are type O- individuals traditionally referred to as “universal donors”?

options.text: Type O- blood lacks surface antigens that could bind to a recipient’s antibodies.
Type O- blood lacks antibodies that could bind to a recipient’s antigens.
Type O- blood lacks platelets so it does not clot after it is donated.
Type O- blood is Rh-negative so it can be donated to a pregnant woman.
Type O- blood lacks the H antigen that could bind to a recipient’s antibodies.

assestmentData.question: A woman with type AB blood marries a man with type O blood. Which of the following lists all the possible blood types their children might have?
Which of the following blood types is an example of codominance?
What is the role of the H antigen on the surface of red blood cells (RBCs)?

options.text: They bind A or B antigens to the RBC surface.
They produce anti-A or anti-B antibodies.
They bind D antigens to the RBC surface.
They signify the condition called Bombay phenotype.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following situations would result in agglutination?

options.text: A patient with type O blood receives type A blood.
A patient with type A blood receives type O blood.
A patient with Rh-positive blood receives Rh-negative blood.
A patient with type AB blood receives type B blood.
A patient with Rh-positive blood receives Rh-positive blood.

Review the background information and activity instructions.
View the following video: Blood Typing with Simulated Blood
Obtain all items listed in “Materials” and PPE.

Examine the blood-typing slide carefully to identify the label for each well: A, B, and Rh. If the lettering is difficult to read, you may wish to write over the letters with a fine-tipped permanent marker.
In Activity 1, you will use simulated antisera to perform <button class='glossary-text'>agglutination</button> tests on simulated blood samples and determine their blood types.

pages.title: Blood Typing with Simulated Blood (10 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Blood Typing with Simulated Blood (10 steps)

pageData.text: Put on PPE (gloves, lab apron, and goggles).
Using the dropper vial, place a drop of simulated blood sample 1 in each well of the blood-typing slide. Replace the cap on the dropper vial.
Caution: Always replace the cap on one vial before opening the next vial to prevent cross-contamination.
Add a drop of simulated anti-A <button class='glossary-text'>serum</button> (blue) to the well labeled “A.” Replace the cap.
Add a drop of simulated anti-B serum (yellow) to the well labeled “B.” Replace the cap.
Add a drop of simulated anti-Rh (anti-D) serum (clear) to the well labeled “Rh.” Replace the cap.
Using a different colored mixing stick for each well (blue for anti-A, yellow for anti-B, white for anti-Rh (anti-D)), gently stir the simulated blood and antiserum drops for 30 seconds.
Caution: Remember to set aside each mixing stick after a single use to avoid sample contamination.

Carefully examine the thin films of liquid mixture that are left behind. If a film remains uniform in appearance, there is no . If the sample appears granular, agglutination has occurred. Determine the blood type of the sample using information in Table 2 as a guide. Establish whether or not agglutination has occurred in each well on the slide.A positive agglutination reaction indicates the blood type. Record your results in Data Table 1.
Document your results by taking a picture of the slide. Document which simulated blood sample was used.
Thoroughly rinse the blood-typing slide, and dry it with a paper towel.
Repeat Steps 2–9 for simulated blood samples 2, 3, and 4.

text: Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment, and return the materials to your equipment kit.
All other investigation materials may be disposed of in the household trash.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.
You will start by setting up the work area and the dissection tools.
In Activity 1, you will examine the dura mater of the intact specimen. Then, you will remove the dura mater of the intact specimen. Next, locate and identify the external structures of the intact specimen.
In Activity 2, you will divide the specimen longitudinally. Then, locate and identify the internal structures of the specimen.

pageData.title: Table 2.
pageData.content: Table 2. Expected agglutination results for common blood types

data.title: A antigen
data.content: A type of red blood cell surface protein used in the ABO blood group system

data.title: ABO group system
data.content: A system for categorizing human blood that denotes the presence of one, both, or neither of the A and B antigens on red blood cells (RBCs)

data.title: Agglutination
data.content: The sticking together of cells into a clump or mass

data.title: Alleles
data.content: Two or more versions of a gene

data.title: Antibodies
data.content: Antigen-binding proteins generated by the immune system

data.title: Antigens
data.content: Molecules on the surface of cells and disease-causing agents

data.title: B antigen
data.content: A type of red blood cell surface protein used in the ABO blood group system

data.title: Bombay phenotype
data.content: A condition in which individuals do not express the H antigen

data.title: Codominance
data.content: A situation in which two different versions of the same gene are both expressed

data.title: Genotype
data.content: The genetic makeup of an individual cell or organism that determines or contributes to the phenotype

data.title: Hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN)
data.content: An often fatal condition that may occur when an Rh-negative woman carries an Rh-positive fetus

data.title: Phenotype
data.content: The physical expression of a trait

data.title: Rh (D) antigen
data.content: A type of red blood cell surface protein used in the Rh blood group system

data.title: Serum
data.content: The liquid portion of the blood without clotting factors
